title: Fizzy pop and juice BANNED from city's leisure centres
text:
Fizzy pop and juice BANNED from city's leisure centres Council bosses have taken the drastic step in a bid to tackle the obesity epidemic among children Share Broughton Baths (Photo: Manchester Evening News) Share   Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Leisure bosses in Salford have banned sugary drinks in a bid to help tackle the city’s obesity epidemic. 
Salford Community Leisure, which run eight centres across the city, has removed sugar-laden fizzy pop and juices from vending machines and cafes. 
It is thought the leisure operator is the first in the country to ban unhealthy drinks. 
Bottled and canned drinks such as cola, lemonade, sports drinks and syrup-heavy slushies have been 
The move comes as a shock report laid bare Salford’s shocking obesity problem, particularly among youngsters. 
Health and council chiefs have raised serious concerns about the huge number of overweight children, who risk heart disease, some cancers and diabetes in later life. Read More Salford's sports centres are set to be replaced or refurbished at a cost of £35m - in a bid to save lives 
Nearly a quarter of four and five-year-old in the city are overweight or obese - and more than third of ten and 11-year-olds. 
Despite high levels of poverty, a staggering 63 pc of residents aged 16 and over are overweight and 27 pc are obese. (Photo: PA) 
Sugary drinks are thought to be a major contributor to the problem, with kids guzzling gallons of pop from an early age. poll loading Do you agree with sugary drinks being banned from sale at leisure facilities? 0+ VOTES SO FAR YES NO 
Bosses in charge of Public Health England’s Change4Life campaign say children between the ages of four and ten consume the equivalent 5,500 sugar cubes A YEAR - around 22kg.
